.- The Opposition will do everything possible to assist the mining industry of Australia, and will strongly resent any attempt to admit free into this country mining machinery which can be manufactured here. By our policy of protection we have compelled the manufacture of mining machinery and treatment plant, which certainly would not have been formulated and developed had we been dependent on other countries. The May and Handcock jig used in the treatment of lead and silver ores, was an Australian invention which was manufactured principally in South Australia. The days of the jigs are passed. The evolution has been from the gravity process to the flotation system. That system was developed in Australia, and subsequently was adopted all over the metalliferous world. Had we depended wholly and exclusively upon other countries for our requirements of mining machinery, there would not have been witnessed the almost miraculous development that has taken place. Heavy metals are now floated instead of being separated by gravity. The natural law has been replaced by an unnatural law. By agitation, by the use of oil and air globules, pieces of zinc or minute particles of lead are picked up and floated off. This system was first invented for the separation of zinc, but it is now being applied to probably a dozen metals, with great benefit to the mining industry. The honorable member for Herbert (Mr. Martens) very rightly pointed out that the cost of mining machinery is not the factor which determines whether a mine is payable or not. If the margin is so small that a proposition can be made a payable or a losing one by the imposition or the non-imposition of a duty on the machinery used in the treatment of the metal - precious or otherwise - it is not. the fault of the machinery, but of the mine itself; or it may be due to mismanagement. In my time I have seen engineers erect plant costing £5,000 - in one case £10,000 - which ten weeks later was dismantled, practically the whole of the machinery being scrapped. The engineers and metallurgists concerned in such experiences have come in for a good deal of harsh criticism, but out of that alleged waste of money has been evolved probably the best system in the world for the treatment of metals. Most of those experiments were carried out at Broken Hill.
There are some complex, intricate; - delicate, if you will - machines that are not yet being manufactured in Australia. In such cases the question to be considered is, whether a duty should be imposed purely for revenue purposes or whether the machines should be allowed in free. I have in mind a modern rotary air drilling machine that was imported into New Zealand from the United States of America by a. company, and is now under offer to an Australian company. This firm, however, is faced with the dilemma that if it purchases the machine and brings it to Australia, it may be involved in the payment of duty amounting to anything up to £6,000. I understand that representations have been made either to the present Minister or his predecessor, or to the officers of the Customs Department, that that machinery - not one part of which is manufactured in Australia - should be allowed in free. The reply received is to the effect that the machine should first be introduced and its value declared, whereupon the matter would be dealt with on its merits.
547
KZR
0 0 WHITE, Thomas Mr White
- It would be necessary to furnish an illustration of the machine, and complete specifications, if the machine could not be examined.
547
JPV
0 0 BLAKELEY, Arthur Mr BLAKELEY
- I believe that the specifications are readily available. In the very near future, a casewill be presented to the Minister, and I trust that he will give it sympathetic consideration.
There is to-day a very great dearth of machinery of a like character. All over Australia, enterprises are being held up for the want of rods, casing, and a lot of other material or machinery that is not manufactured in Australia, and that will not be manufactured here until petroleum is discovered, and there is a better demand for it. I therefore suggest to the Minister that the most sympathetic consideration should be given to the question of importing machinery from overseas for the pioneering of a new industry such as that of petroleum prospecting. I am quite convinced that, with such assistance from the Government, much more, can be done in Australia in that direction than is being done to-day.
Amendment negatived.
Sub-items (b) to (f) agreed to.
Progress reported.
House adjourned at 1 1 p.m.

para.inline: The following answers to questions were circulated: -

talk.start.para: y asked ths Attorney-General, upon notice -

item.para: With reference to various societies and companies that are in liquidation, is there any provision made that when the affairs of such societies and companies are finalized all the papers and books shall be placed in charge of a government department?

If not, in view of. proposals being made to burn all books and papers on the completion of the liquidation, will the Minister consider the passing of legislation to prevent such suggested action being carried out, and to provide that the destructionof documents should take place at the end of, say, 50 years?

talk.start.para: - The liquidation of companies is a matter that falls within the province of the States, and the Commonwealth has no power under the Constitution to pass legislation on the lines suggested by the honorable member.
n asked the Postmaster-General, upon notice -

item.para: Is it a fact that serious interference with road transport services in Tasmania is occurring, due to the State Transport Committee refusing licences for vehicles carrying mails between Hobart and Bothwell, and Launceston and Georgetown?
If so, will he take such action as will ensure effective Federal and State co-ordination in the letting of contracts for the carriage of mails?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follow : -

item.para: There has been no interference with mail transport facilities.
The department is already working in co-operation with the Tasmanian Transport Committee.

subdebateinfo.title: Royal Australian Navy : Transfer of British Warships

talk.start.para: y asked the Prime Minister, upon notice -

item.para: With reference to the negotiations reported to be taking place between the British and Commonwealth Governments for the transfer of destroyers and cruisers of the Royal Navy to Australia, would such transfer enable the British Government to build new ships in place of the vessels transferred, thereby creating employment for shipyard workers in Great Britain?

In view of the serious unemployment existing in Australia, especially amongst those trained in ship construction, will the Government, when considering any proposals for the re-organization of, or additions to, Australia's naval defence, take into consideration the interests of idle shipbuilding establishments in Australia, and the thousands of unemployed artisans?

talk.start.para: (through Mr. Latham). - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follow : -

item.para: No. The Royal Australian Navy is included in Empire tonnage.
The matter will receive the full consideration of the Government.

talk.start.para: y asked the Prime Minister, upon notice -

quote.para: By whom was the independent valuation of the Commonwealth ships made in June, 1932?

talk.start.para: (through Mr. Latham). - The name of the company which made the independent valuation is C. W. Kellock and Company Limited, 27-31 St: Mary Axe, London, E.C.3.
y asked the Minister for Trade and Customs, upon notice -

item.para: Whether the statistical figures of imports for the year 1931-32 show that the duty-free goods were valued at £18,925,708, that the value of dutiable goods, according to customs methods, was £25,787,160, and that the revenue received amounted to £18,565,630, or an average rate of 77 per cent.?
Is 10 per cent. added to the value of dutiable goods?
With this 10 per cent. deducted, does it raise the average rate imposed during 1931-32 to approximately 80 per cent.?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follow: -

item.para: No. There is a serious fallacy in the suggestion made. With few exceptions, there are now no goods entirely free of duty, as a revenue duty in the form of primage covers nearly all imports. In the calculation made the primage on free goods has been charged against the value of the dutiable goods. Again the equivalent ad valorem rate includes many essentially revenue duties at fixed rates. Spirits are typical of these, and the ad valorem equivalent of the revenue duty may be 300 per cent. or 400 per cent. This greatly affects the general average. On these goods Great Britain charges much higher duties than the Commonwealth does.
Yes.
See answer to No. 1.

talk.start.para: s asked the Attorney-General, upon notice -

item.para: Is it a fact that in September, 1927, an extensive library comprising a collection of scarce and valuable official and other patent records was proffered as a gift to the Federal Government, through the then Commissioner of Patents, and was acceptedby that officer and the Bight Honorable the Attorney-General ?
If so, what does this literary collection include, and will he afford this House an approximate estimate of what the same would now cost?
Was the collection accepted, and have these records been made accessible to the public?
Will he place on the table of this House a copy of any correspondence concerning the matter ?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follow : -

item.para: Yes, Mr. Fred Walsh, Patent Attorney of Sydney, donated a portion of his technical library in 1927 to the Commonwealth, and received the thanks of the Commonwealth Government.
The collection consists of early British and American patent records, together with a number of technical journals, but it is quite impossible to assess the value of same.
Yes. On application, the records are made available to the public.
The papers will be made available to the honorable member on application.

talk.start.para: (through Mr Latham). - On the 21st March, the honorable member forForrest (Mr. Prowse) asked the following question,without notice: -

quote.para: I have received from Mr. Gladstone, Mayor of Wagin, Western Australia, the following telegram : -

Understand it is intention of Commonwealth Savings Bank to convert various sub-branches to agencies. These comprise Wagin, York, Beverley, and other offices which were formerly full branches of the old State Savings Bank and are still conducted by State officials. This council strongly protests.
Another telegram from Western Australia makes a similar protest. Will the Prime Minister exert his powerful influence to prevent the removal of an important convenience from these growing towns?

question.para: The following information has been supplied by the Commonwealth Bank: -

quote.para: There will be no removal of important conveniences as suggested in the question by the honorable member for Forrest. The cancellation from sub-branch to agency is more a matter of name than alteration in methods. All conveniences which depositors have had in the past they will still enjoy, with the only exception that withdrawals of amounts in excess of £20 will be referred to the central office. The new arrangements provide both for added economy and more effective control.

subdebateinfo.title: Monetary Policy of the United States of America.

talk.start.para: (through Mr. Latham).- On the 14th March, the honorable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr. Holloway) asked the following question, upon notice : -

quote.para: In view of the serious nature of the banking crisis in the United States of America, and its possible affect upon Australia and other countries, will he inform the House what percentage of the banking and/or monetary system of the United States of America is in the hands of private enterprise, and what percentage is owned and controlled by the Government of the United States of America?
The answer to the honorable member's question is as follows: -

It is not possible with the information avail able to ascertain the extent of government ownership of banks in the United States of America. The extent of control both as to the number of bunks and magnitude of their operation is also unknown. For the beat infornmtion available on this subject the honorable member is referred to the following publications : - The Reserve Ranks and the Money Market, by W. Randolph Burgess, and The Statistical A bstract of the United States, issued by the United States of America Department of Commerce, which should he read in conjunction with recent American banking legislation.

talk.start.para: l. - On the 1.7th March, the honorable member for Cook (Mr.Riley) asked the following questions, upon notice : -

item.para: What costs were incurred in the Mail Branch, Sydney, for (a) salaries and/or wages; and (b) overtime, for the years ended30th June, 1926, 1927, 1928, 1929, 1930, 1931, and 1932?

What number of (a) assistant superintendents of mails, (b) supervisors, (c) mail officers, and (d) temporary employees, were employed in the Mail Branch, Sydney, for the years ended 30th June, 1926, 1927, 1928, 1929, 1930, 1931, and 1932?
What expenditure was incurred in the installation of sorting presses and equipment in the Mail Branch, Central Square, Sydney, during the twelve months ended 30th June, 1929?
What expenditure was incurred in the installation of machinery and equipment for handling of mails in the Mail Branch, General Post Office, Sydney, up to 30th September, 1930?
What expenditure has been incurred since 1st October, 1930, in effecting alterations and/or additions to the machinery and equipment in the Mail Branch, General Post Office, Sydney?
What number of officers and/or employees is engaged on the control and maintenance of the machine-handling plant in the Mai! Branch, General Post Office, Sydney?
What annual expenditure is incurred in the control and maintenance of the machinehandling plant, Mail Branch, General Post Office, Sydney, for (a) salariesand/or wages, and (b) electric power?

question.para: I am now in a position to inform the honorable member as follows: -

item.para: Expenditure as at 30th September, 1930, not available,but expenditure up to 30th June, 1931, £150,41 1.

Expenditure for the period 1st October, 1930, to 30th June, 1931, is included in the amount given in No. 4. For the period 1st July, 1931, to 30th June, 1932, the information is as follows : - Alterations, £795; additions, £4,134. Total, £4,929.
Full time- 13; half time- 16.

talk.start.para: - On the 17th March, the honorable member for Capricornia (Mr. Forde) asked whether it was a fact that the Moth aircraft now in the possession of the Rockhampton Aero Club is to be sent to Brisbane ? I am now in a position to inform the honorable member that the Defence Department is not aware of any proposal to send the Moth aircraft now on loan to the Rockhampton Aero Club to Brisbane. This Moth was damaged in an accident last October, and the Rockhampton Club have not as yet been able to finance its repair or replacement as their agreement requires them to do in such circumstances. The sugges tion has been made, however, that the RockhamptonClub should join forces with the main Queensland AeroClub which is located at Brisbane, following the procedure recently adopted in similar circumstances by the Ballarat Aero Club and the Victorian AeroClub, Melbourne. This suggestion was made with a view to arriving at a practicable basis of operations whereby the Queensland Aero Club, in taking over the responsibility for the repair of the damaged Rockhampton machine and its subsequent operation and maintenance as portion of its fleet of loaned aircraft, would contract with the department to provide facilities at Rockhampton for the members of the local aero club tq obtain instruction and practice in flying at' the rate normally chargeable to club members in .Brisbane and elsewhere. It would appear that such a basis of operations would not only free the Rockhampton Club of its present difficulty as regards the cost of repair of the damaged aircraft, but also "would restore to Rockhampton residents the facilities for instructional and practice flying which are unavailable to them as a result of the local club being unable to place their Moth in flying order. It is thought that a merger on the lines of the above suggestion could probably be negotiated between the Rockhampton and Brisbane Clubs to the mutual advantage of each organization. The .Rockhampton Club has been informed, however, that their representations in favour of financial assistance by the Government 1.0 enable them to repair their Moth and continue their operations as a separate body will receive the department's consideration.
